title: How to be a good writer in English? I'm not a native speaker. I have studied a writing course this semester and my marks are not good. How can I improve my writing skills - Quora

response.answer_text: I have a technical background. ‘I think a lot of people get into technical subjects because they don’t like to write. Paradoxically, people get higher positions in Technical areas if they know how to put together well written proposals to get money for projects. After I was out of the country for several years, I wanted to speak better and write better. I was not interested in literature or history or in writing about them. I was interested in writing generally or from a scientific perspective. One professor at USC asked “What is ‘good’ writing?” He concluded that good writing is what people considered to be good writers do. There are a number of books to help us to become better writers. I also learned a lot after I did a lot of writing and taught writing. At one point, I was on a writing project and another person on the project said “whatever Don says, use that because it is what we want to say.” A US Navy captain gave me the text to edit and he made the changes in the word file. Oh, do some editing. It is easier to edit the writing of others than it is to edit our own writing. The process is to write something, let is rest for a few days, then edit what you wrote. Edit then rewrite for about 5 or 6 times. Then let someone else look at it. Others may have some objective views on what you wrote. One last thing—be more concerned that your ideas are clear to you. The grammar and spelling can be reviewed by someone who is a better speaker of English than you. It takes years. Read a bunch of stuff, edit some writing. (Some books are not well-written.) Read some advice on writing critically.

I’d recommend reading, speaking, and writing in English as much as possible. Reading will show you how accomplished writers shape their words. But the key is not to copy what they do. For example, reading the classics is a great help in building your knowledge and vocabulary, but a lot of the “classics” were written decades or centuries ago so the language is old-fashioned and the styles very distinctive. Your own writing still needs to be your own. I’d suggest reading current popular writers as well as the “classic” authors. Practicing your spoken English, with native speakers if possible, will also help a lot. Most people write very much like they speak: that’s how it comes out sounding natural. Just keep in mind that spoken English can be informal, so sometimes your writing might need to be more formal. Most importantly, keep practicing your writing! Writing well in any language is hard and English is particularly hard. If you can, ask a native speaker to read your writing and ask them how they would have written it. Grammar and style books can help, but a real reader can best tell you if your writing is clear and readable.

It takes time and practice. You might try the free app that allows you to dictate - if you dictate you don't need to spell, you can just think. It doesn't help everybody but it does help some people. Write sentences. Just sentences. Writing courses usually don't start with sentences. They ask for essays but you can't write a good essay if your sentence writing isn't strong. Write ten sentences every day and have someone edit them for you. Write simple sentences until you're getting them correct and then move on to compound sentences. Write ten separate sentences - not a paragraph - about the perfect birthday party.

Hi; the best way is by reading. From the classics like Jane Austen to Charles Dickens to Evelyn Waugh. Modern writers like Kate Atkinson, Tana French. Also if you can get your hands on back copies of the London Review of Books and the Times Literary Review; or for a US approach, the New York Review of Books and the New Yorker magazine. Newspaper and magazine websites are usually subscription only. However, the Guardian can be generous, as is the New Statesman, both politically left of centre. . . or the Spectator, right of centre.

Firs of all, you SHOULD read a lot of books in English. That will help you to improve your writing skills. Secondly, you can install extensions (like gramaticaly, translators and dictionaries) on your browser (for example, google crome). The next step is just writing as much as you can. Hope you will deal with this ;)

Keep at it. Most writers say they have improved their writing by doing more writing. Having friends who will read some of your work out loud may help; they may comment, and you’ll have ideas of your own from hearing them read. Joseph Conrad (1857–1924) spoke no English as a child or in his youth and became one of the greatest English-language writers of his time.
improve your English writing skills = have a look at the British Broadcasting Corporation (BBC) website “BBC Learning English”. There are lots of tips and help to improve your writing.
